thread.title: Selfie sticks banned in Central Park Zoo, museums around NYC
thread.title_full: Selfie sticks banned in Central Park Zoo, museums around NYC

author: MATT YOUNG
title: Selfie sticks banned in Central Park Zoo, museums around NYC
text:
THE revolution has begun.
The city of New York has taken the dramatic step of banning selfie sticks in its Museums and Zoos — citing serious threats of danger to the public, exhibits and animals.
The selfie stick, listed in Time magazine’s 25 Best Inventions of 2014, became the hottest item of the year, struggling to meet with ever-increasing demand.
The device allows users to hold their smartphones through a retractable stick, in order to capture incredible selfies from a distance.
“It was one of the most popular Christmas gifts,” Andy Brennan, an analyst at researcher IBISWorld told skift.com .
“Every retailer I spoke with about selfie sticks sold out and had to resupply.”
It all began when the Museum of Modern Art officially banned the use of the devices, yet a spokesperson told news.com.au that technically, “for the safety of our visitors and the museum’s works of art we have never permitted visitors to take photos with any camera devices”.
After all, no one wants to be responsible for ripping a Warhol in half, right?
Soon enough, others followed suit.
Central Park Zoo has taken the drastic step of erecting a sign alerting tourists to the selfie stick ban. Oh, and watch out for those balloons. Source: Supplied
“Photography is not permitted beyond the rotunda floor and the museum does not allow the use of selfie sticks,” a spokesperson from The Guggenheim told Gothamist .
The Frick Musem, which houses the likes of Bellini and Rembrandt, has made a point to take note of the ban on its website .
“You can, just by looking at this, imagine the havoc a selfie stick might wreak in this kind of space,” Jennifer Northrup of the Cooper-Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, told CBS.com .
No flash, no comercial photo, no selfie-stick BUT SELFIES ARE FINE "Shootbklyn: My kind of place…. http://t.co/hqH28yo0Gi " #MuseumSelfie Day
— Lola Liquete (@lolaliquete) January 21, 2015 Central Park Zoo is so passionate about the issue it has erected a sign alerting tourists of the ban, claiming “they are dangerous to our animals”.
Numerous attempts to contact the Zoo went unanswered.
It follows similar bans in Australia including Sydney’s Qantas Credit Union Arena, Melbourne’s Etihad Stadium, the Domain Stadium in WA, Perth Arena, and Suncorp stadium in Brisbane.
So beware, travellers, that beloved selfie stick could land you in a whole lot of trouble, and not just on your Instagram feed.
